data.title: Election Watch
data.text:
At stake in this election:

Seats in the Legislative Council: 60

Description of government structure:

Head of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region: Chief Executive TUNG Chee-hwa

Legislature: Hong Kong's unicameral Legislative Council (LEGCO) consists of 60 members.

Description of electoral system:

In the Legislative Council: 24 members are popularly elected by a system of proportional representation, 30 members are elected by 28 functional constituencies, representing various sectors of the community, and the remaining six members are elected by an Election Committee. All members serve four year terms.

*Note: See below for changes in the electoral structure specific to this election.

Main parties in the electoral races:

Party: Democratic Party (DP)

Leader: Martin LEE Chu-ming

Seats won in last election: 13

Party: Democratic Alliance for the Betterment of Hong Kong (DAB)

Leader: Jasper TSANG Yok-sing

Seats won in last election: 10

Party: Hong Kong Progressive Alliance (HKPA)

Leader: Ambrose LAU Hon-chuen

Seats won in last election: 5

Party: The Frontier (TF)

Leader: Emily LAU Wai-hang

Seats won in last election: 4

Party: Liberal Party (LP)

Leader: James TIEN

Seats won in last election: 10

When was the last election? Number of seats in last election?

Last Election to the Legislative Council: May 25, 1998

Seats decided in the last election: 60

Population and number of registered voters:

Population: 6,847,125 (July 1999 est.)

Number of registered voters: 3,055,378

Of Interest:

For the September 2000 election, the number of popularly elected seats in the Legislative Council will be increased from 20 to 24 seats, while the number of seats elected by the Election Committee has been reduced from ten to six seats. The term of office has been increased from two to four-years.

The September 2000 election will be the second popular election to the Legislative Council since the People's Republic of China took control of Hong Kong on July 1st 1997.

SOURCE: INTERNATIONAL FOUNDATION FOR ELECTION SYSTEMS (IFES)
